ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How to write good fiction. Simple as that.

I entered this class without any training in creative writing, and little practice on my own. I left with a sense of my writing voice and what generally makes a story work. This class helped me develop personal taste regarding other short stories, practice giving feedback on others' work, and knowledge about where to begin when I'm trying to write my own story.

I learned how to closely examine short stories in order to see how writers developed characters, plot, structure, and vivid descriptions. I took these observations and learned how to implement them in my own writing. By the end of the course, I completed a full short story inspired by one of the readings earlier in the course.

I have a much better understanding of how to think about, read, and write fiction. I loved the opportunity to think slowly and carefully about each element of craft before sitting down and trying to work with them all.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths:
- Learned what I want to do with the rest of my life
- Found my purpose as an academic and a person
- Learned that similes are incredibly stupid unless done right, which is rare and fun
- Never gonna get a better professor than Michael
- Trie encouragement and a lovely environment 
- Awesome readings and exercises
- Workshop rules <3

Weaknesses:
- Sometimes classes can feel long, which the five-minute break helps with. Not a flaw of the course, just my own attention span. Michael lets us sit outside in the warmer weeks, which absolutely helps a lot.

The course was strongest when we got to debate about whether we felt a story worked -- my favorite stories we read in class were the most controversial. I think it would be good to lean into that, reading more unconventional stories or works that have been publicly criticized.

This course is absolutely fantastic, a highlight of my time at Yale. Its strengths lie in the professor's insightful teaching, the choice of stories we read for inspiration, and a collaborative and welcoming environment of students. It would have been nice to submit a draft of our short stories earlier on in the semester in order to produce a more polished second draft, but that is my only recommendation.

The structure of the course -- writing exercises that lead to writing a full story -- was a huge strength. I appreciated the time to get my bearings before jumping in. The reading list was fantastic, and the workshops were very helpful. The only improvement I could think of would be having a revision -- there's obviously not time during the semester, but it might have been nice to have a revision due during finals period so that we could implement the workshop advice.

Prof Cunningham is incredibly kind and personable. He holds weekly office hours for his students and will always send you additional materials to read and discuss. The other students in this class were also engaged and talented writers (but that shouldn't discourage someone from applying to the course). However, there was a noticeable lack of diversity in the class. Every single student was white, which I thought was the one true draw-back of this course. We did not have a variety of perspectives when discussing the works, and certainly not the works that dealt with topics of race.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you're even a little interested in persuing fiction writing, take this class and take it with Michael Cunningham.
Yes! This class was the highlight of my week. I think anyone who loves to read, regardless of whether they've done any creative writing before, would appreciate this class a lot.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student! If you have any interest in learning to write fiction, to improve your writing quality, and read fantastic short stories, take this class. I was nervous to take this class since I'm not an English major, but it was a good mix of English and non-English majors. Almost everyone in the class was new to writing fiction, so we were all at a similar level to start.
Absolutely! If you have any interest in reading and writing stories, you should take this class if given the opportunity.
I definitely would recommend this course to another student. If you have the opportunity to take Prof Cunningham's section of English 404, definitely do.
